it's exactly the same thing that works on both Windows and Linux first or in the containers so what's different they
need to consider so the first thing is that when you're actually deploying the windows
applications we need to make sure that they were actually run on a Windows node and so the that that's where the node
selectors come into place but if today you're running a whole lot of Linux apps and you haven't been using node
selectors then the other thing you could do is before you add a Windows node in
and make it scheduled well you can add you could go ahead and add a taint on it
so that way things one could schedule on it so if Windows is going to be too
minority of your deployment then that's probably going to make sense to go ahead and put the taint on the nodes and then
when you deploy the Windows apps you just put a node selector and the Toleration on it so in your Windows apps
will run on Windows nodes and everything else will just default to Linux so that'd be an easy way that you can do it
across the board and then that gives you you know time to go back and update your helmet arts as needed to have the node
selectors in there the other thing that I want to call out is that the resource
consumption for Windows containers is higher that's because Windows every time
you start a Windows container a bunch of background services they're needed to do things like you know run the users
security database be able to handle background processes like the web
servers all those need to be replicated for each container so if you go and actually look at the number of processes
running within a given pod it's going to be a lot higher than a number of processes you're going to see
on linux and that's just due to the difference in operating systems
there okay so the question was about the higher resource consumption and so every
time you start a Windows container it's got a bear set of processes that it needs and that's going to be consistent
whether or not you're using kubernetes that's just the way that the windows container is run and I'll show you that
real quick so if I do if I exact into my web pod here around PowerShell
we've got the dash
so if I look at get process and I look at all these processes that are here you
know these are all the background processes and I'm talking about it looks like there's what twelve different
service hosts we're actually why am i counting this
well we could see so we got 11 service hosts I've got the web process plus all these other ones running and so that's
just part of what starts up every time you start up the container there and there's another question on the left
yeah so the mode we're running in right now all the containers are sharing the
same kernel as the host but where there are system processes that need to have that have different views of things like
the user database that's where they must be duplicated per container yes so
what's elevated in the container has no privileges on the host it's a completely
different security database and so things like the file permissions are resolved within the context of that
container not on the host so like the recommend best practice on Linux have often seen is don't use don't
use root in your container because if you break out you've got the same user ID and now you've got privileges being
resolved based on that UID on the host that's not true on Windows because the
databases are completely separate if I create two containers with the same username the security identifiers under
that are actually written out to the file system are different they're different from the hosts they're different from each other and so if you
do need to create multiple users in a container then you actually do that as part of your docker file build you can
do a net user slash add user one that user slash add user two and then you can
Akal things appropriately and all of that will be resolved within the context of that container the other
clarification point there is we don't support the privileged flag on windows so there is no way to assert those
privileges so that you could do things like change network interfaces or mount points on the host it's just not
possible we it's always blocked
and so just to clarify on the Colonel thing because right now they all share the same Colonel there's a lot of
Windows user mode binaries like ntdll and user 32 where you for whatever
reason when Windows was developed they took a lot of api's and actually implemented them in kernel mode that's a
problem for containerization because the user mode binary is just a shim that's
just going to do a context switch and then operate it in kernel mode and what that means is so those api's need to
match the kernel that's running on the host so if you build a container on Windows Server 2000 19 you need to run
it on Server 2019 and likewise if you're using another version like 1803 or 2016
the same applies there the way that we're working on addressing that is using hyper-v isolation because with
hyper-v we can actually boot up the match and kernel that you need for that container so that way the user kernel
boundary matches again and then you also get that extra layer of isolation that's something that is always done on Windows
10 like if you're using docker cee on a Windows 10 laptop every time you take
